title: My parents say I suck at singing. My friends say I sound like the lead singer of The Cranberries. I got a gold medal at a large singing contest. Why do my parents tell me to shut up, that I suck, and to quit singing? I'm a 16-year-old female. - Quora

response.answer_text: Please allow me to guess a bit here, based on my experience. I have won a couple of amateur singing contests, nothing big, and I used to get many comments from folks who felt I sounded better than most professionals. Now, about 27 years after I last actively sang, whether performing or being in a choir, my 12-year old son thinks I suck!… just hearing me singing around the house and in the car. Granted, the combination of heavy intake of spicy food, bourbon and frequently yelling at the computer screen (daily trading can do that to you!) has killed my falsetto, shrunk my comfort zone from more than 3 1/2 octaves to about 2+ and made my voice unexpectedly break up occasionally. Yet, I feel like I, generally, can still hold notes properly within my natural bass baritone range and am capable of using techniques to compensate for my now many shortcomings. So, why the harsh criticisms from my son, besides perhaps being in his phase of rebellious adolescence? My guesses are… My singing style ranges from big band, Broadway to some ballads, all of which Alex considers ‘old, and no one listens…’ So, I suck because I sing in styles he dislikes. Similarly, The Cranberries’ unique (at least when they first came out) compositional and vocal style may not be what your parents are used to. To them, you may simply sound offkey and odd.I sing around the kitchen and in the car, neither of which is acoustically complementary. Except for maybe soft, lyrical and contemplative ballads, most everyday environments aren’t appropriate for real singing — the diaphragm pushing, big voice-type of singing. So, when you sing around the house and car, you can’t really sing all out, and, on top of that, you don’t have electronic echoes and amplification to make up for deficit.As much as my parents feel that I am a decent singer, they have never once encouraged me to pursue singing as a career. (I have always felt that I sing only for enjoyment anyway, so there’s no conflict there.) Your parents may see your talent as a sideshow to your studies and later your ‘normal’ career! Not too many parents, especially non-musicians, would encourage their kids to pursue a less-structured career path such as in music or other arts. It is a hard and less predictable career path if you so choose it, so perhaps they are making a conscious effort to discourage you early on, whether they see your talent or not.So, what to do? May I suggest that you make sure your academic performance is up to your potential, alleviating your parents’ potential objections. Then, you join a band or choir in school while keeping the hours of practice within your parents’ mental limits, as a way to channel your musical creativity. Once you get into college, you can major in a more ‘practical’ field (computer, logistics, business…) and minor in music and performing arts. This way, you can keep peace with your parents, get a degree you can fall back on, get a taste of multiple fields and then decide for yourself what you want to do with your life. The best IT manager I have ever met was a trained operatic soprano. Bette majored in music and minored in art history, and landed a job at an art museum, where she learnt a lot about computers. She later became a VP in an IT department in a major brokerage firm. All the while, she continued to train in her singing. (She was one of the two Classical music nuts I could talk to while I worked for the said brokerage firm.) It goes to show that you will never know where the adventure we called life may take you. As a person on his fourth career, I can attest to that. Keep your love of music alive within your heart. It might become your career, or it might not, but with music in your heart, you’ll never be alone. Whether you have the talent or still need further training, you will figure it out and decide for yourself! (It does sound like you do, though.) No one else can or should do that for you! Best wishes to you!
